Controls.Description: All users/identities must be granted minimum required permissions using Role Based Access Control (RBAC)
Controls.Rationale: Granting minimum access by leveraging RBAC feature ensures that users are granted just enough permissions to perform their tasks. This minimizes exposure of the resources in case of user/service account compromise.
Controls.Recommendation: Remove any excessive privileges granted on the CDN. Run command Remove-AzRoleAssignment -SignInName '{signInName}' -Scope '{scope}' -RoleDefinitionName '{role definition name}'. Run 'Get-Help Remove-AzRoleAssignment -full' for more help.

Controls.Description: CDN profile endpoints must use token authentication
Controls.Rationale: Using token authentication prevents Azure CDN from serving assets to unauthorized clients. This keeps other sites from 'hotlinking' content and using your assets without permission
Controls.Recommendation: To enable token authentication (currently available on Premium Verizon tier), go to Azure Portal --> your CDN Profile --> Manage --> HTTP LARGE --> Token Auth. Please refer https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/cdn/cdn-token-auth for more details on token authentication.

Controls.Description: Token encryption key must be protected in a key vault (when a website generates tokens via code).
Controls.Rationale: Keeping secrets such as DB connection strings, passwords, keys, etc. in clear text can lead to easy compromise at various avenues during an application's lifecycle. Storing them in a key vault ensures that they are protected at rest.
Controls.Recommendation: Refer https://azure.microsoft.com/en-in/documentation/articles/key-vault-get-started/ (Key Vault) and  https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/cdn/cdn-token-auth (token-based authentication in CDN).

Controls.Description: CDN endpoints must use HTTPS protocol while providing data to the client browser/machine or while fetching data from the origin server
Controls.Rationale: Use of HTTPS ensures server/service authentication and protects data in transit from network layer man-in-the-middle, eavesdropping, session-hijacking attacks.
Controls.Recommendation: To enable HTTPS protocol: Go to Azure Portal --> your CDN Profile --> your CDN Endpoint --> Origin --> Select HTTPS --> Save. Else implement through PowerShell as follows: `$ce= Get-AzCdnEndpoint -EndpointName <EndpointName> -ProfileName <CDNprofile> -ResourceGroupName <RGName>; `$ce.IsHttpAllowed =`$false; `$ce.IsHttpsAllowed =`$true; Set-AzCdnEndpoint -CdnEndpoint `$ce

Controls.Description: Do not put any sensitive data in a CDN. CDN is suitable only for resources where anonymous access is not a concern
Controls.Rationale: Azure CDN does not provide any access control feature to restrict/secure access to content. Thus no private data should be stored in CDN.

Controls.Description: Configure real time alerts on status code 403 to be observant of any unauthorized request for CDN endpoint
Controls.Rationale: Setting up real-time alerts provides real-time notifications about the performance of the endpoints and any unauthorized request in your CDN profile.
Controls.Recommendation: To set up alerts: Go to Azure Portal --> your CDN Profile --> Manage --> Analytics --> Real-Time Stats --> Real-Time Alerts.
